g.text: according to a recent evaluation report, the integration of gender into ope
programme is fragmented and there is lack of an ‘adequate, systematic and comprehensive gender
equality approach for the allocation and distribution of funds for projects and programmes on the
half of the analysed sample of 70 climate projects were judged to be largely gender
considered to have successfully mainstreamed gender, including in two Least Developed Countries
es funding proposals to consider gender impact as part of their investment framework
does not have its own funding stream targeted to women’s project on the ground, nor is there as yet an
evaluation as to how entities are actually implementing
gender action plan in the projects. In the case
of the CIFs, as noted by
, ‘gender is not included in the operational principles of the
Pilot Program on Climate Resilience (PPCR), which funds programmatic adaptation portfolios in a few
countries, although most pilot countries have included some gender dimensions’. And,
‘gender is not integrated into the operations of the Clean Technology Fund (CTF), which finances large
scale mitigation in large economies and accounts for 70
. However, both the Forest Investment Program (FIP) and the Scaling
Income Countries Program (SREP) have integrated gender equality as
Overall, efforts to promote gender responsive/sensitive climate finance, at national and local levels,
both in the public and private dimensions and more specifically in mitigation
markets in the areas of social bond are focused around gender bonds
activities and behaviours that are relevant to gender equality and
linked Bonds as well as Social Bonds Principles of the International
Capital Market Association. Issuances of gender
labelled bonds are increasing in the Asia Pacific region
ensive initiative is the Impact Investment Exchange’s (IIX) multi
) and in Latin America, Columbia, Mexico and Panama each have
gender bond issuances). Additionally, a few developing countries, such as Paki
Morocco (March 2021) have issued gender bond guidelines for financial market participants.
Linkage to sectoral climate change issues and gender and climate finance
designed to enhance women’s more formal integration
into climate policies, programmes and actions
by the global private sector include: investment in clean energy, redirecting funds to support women
and vulnerable region as a component of social and green bonds as well as insurance for climate risk
nt. In the latter context, insurance providers are arguing that ‘given the fact that women are
disproportionately affected by climate change, there could be new finance innovations to address this
gap.’ AXA and IFC estimate that the global women’s insuranc
e market has the opportunity to grow to
three times its current size, to 1.7 trillion USD by 2030
(AXA Group et al. 2015; GIZ et al. 2017)
However, across the board and in particular with regard to public funds, despite improvements in the
ubstantive gender sensitization and operational gender responsiveness of multilateral and bilateral
climate finance funds operations, current flows of public and climate finance do not seem to be going
Notably, the GCF provides guidance to Accredited Entities submitting funding proposals on the
inclusion of an initial gender and social assessment during the project planning, preparation and development
stage and a gender and social inclusion ac
tion plan at the project preparation stage.
The WLB series has been on the market since 2017 when WLB1 was launched. WLB2 issuance of
$12 million arrived January 2020. WLB 3was launched December 2020
entrepreneurs in the Asia Pacific to respond, to recover from, and to build resilience in the aftermath
